evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Congress enacted the Consumer Product Safety Act (CPSA), Pub. L. No. 92-573, 86 Stat. 1207, in 1972 to “protect the public against unreasonable risks of injury associated with consumer products,” to “assist consumers in evaluating the comparative safety of consumer products,” to “develop uniform safety standards for consumer products and to minimize conflicting State and local regulations,” and to “promote research and investigation into the causes and prevention of product-related deaths, illnesses, and injuries.” 15 U.S.C. § 2051(b).

extracted.value: Congress enacted the Consumer Product Safety Act (CPSA) in 1972 to protect the public against unreasonable risks of injury associated with consumer products

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Congress created the CPSC as an “independent regulatory commission” composed of five Commissioners with “background and expertise in areas related to consumer products and protection of the public from risks to safety.” Id. § 2053(a). Commissioners are appointed by the President and confirmed by the Senate, id., to serve staggered, seven-year terms, id. § 2053(b)(1), with the possibility under certain circumstances of serving up to an additional year pending installation of a successor, id. § 2053(b)(2).

extracted.value: CPSC created as independent regulatory commission with five Commissioners appointed by President and confirmed by Senate

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: To ensure the independence of the CPSC Commissioners, Congress provided that they could be “removed by the President” prior to the end of their terms only “for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office but for no other cause.” Id. § 2053(a).

extracted.value: Commissioners can only be removed for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Plaintiff Mary Boyle was confirmed on June 22, 2022, to serve out the remainder of her predecessor’s seven-year term, which expires on October 27, 2025. Plaintiff Alexander Hoehn-Saric was confirmed on October 7, 2021, to serve out the remainder of his predecessor’s seven-year term, which expires on October 27, 2027. Plaintiff Richard Trumka Jr. was confirmed on November 16, 2021, for a term expiring on October 27, 2028.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs Boyle, Hoehn-Saric, and Trumka confirmed by Senate with terms expiring 2025-2028

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: On May 8, 2025, Plaintiffs Boyle and Trumka received emails from Trent Morse, Deputy Director of Presidential Personnel. The bodies of the emails stated, in their entirety: “On behalf of President Donald J. Trump, I am writing to inform you that your position on the Consumer Product Safety Commission is terminated effective immediately. Thank you for your service.”

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: On May 9, Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric and his staff arrived at CPSC offices. CPSC security prevented Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric and his staff from going to their offices but allowed them to stay in the lobby. Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric made multiple attempts to call Defendant Peter A. Feldman, Acting Chairman of the CSPC. After Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric had waited in the lobby for approximately an hour, Defendant Feldman called and informed Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric that the President had terminated Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric from his role as CPSC Commissioner and that Plaintiff Hoehn-Saric should leave. Defendant Feldman did not identify any neglect of duty or malfeasance in office as justification for the purported termination.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs received termination emails without justification on May 8-9, 2025

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: To effectuate Plaintiffs’ purported terminations, Defendant Feldman has prevented Plaintiffs from executing their duties as Commissioners, including by barring their access to their offices and agency email accounts, and by terminating personnel who staff Plaintiffs’ offices.

extracted.value: Defendants prevented Plaintiffs from executing duties by barring office access and terminating staff
